tossups.answer: María Eva Perón [accept Evita Péron; prompt on Péron]<World History, AK><ed. JB>   Bonuses

answers: Rastafari [accept Rastafarianism while frowning with disapproval]
parts: Name this Abrahamic religious practice developed in Jamaica, whose adherents believe that Africa is the Promised Land of Zion.
Rastafaris revere this Jamaican-born leader of the Back-to-Africa movement, who founded the Universal Negro Improvement Association and the Black Star Line.
Another reverential figure in Rastafari tradition is Haile Selassie I, who became associated with Christ in this proto-Rastafari text written by Robert Athlyi Rogers.

answers: Self-Strengthening Movement [accept Tongzhi Restoration or Western Affairs Movement]
parts: His claim to fame began with his ruthless suppression of this 1850 millenarian Chinese rebellion. It was led by the self-proclaimed brother of Christ, Hong Xiuquan, who ruled a namesake Heavenly Kingdom based in Nanjing.
It's not the hundred days reforms, but Tso also founded China's first modern shipyard as part of these never-completed reforms that were cancelled by the Empress Dowager.
General Tso is also credited with briefly halting the expansion of this largest European country, whose Trans-Siberian Railroad threatened China's Central Asian possessions.

answers: Möbius function <Other Science, CT><ed. VS and AB>
parts: Name this mathematician who also names an approximation for definite integrals calculated by summing up a finite series of areas. The trapezoid rule and Simpson’s rule are special cases of that kind of sum.
One of the Millenium Prize Problems conjectures that all of the nontrivial roots of this function named after Riemann have real part one-half.

A Dirichlet series that generates this function is equal to the reciprocal of the Riemann zeta function for values with real part greater than 1. This function is equal to either -1, 0, or 1 depending on the input’s prime factorization.
Name this novel centering around Toru Watanabe’s relationships with Naoko and Midori.
Norwegian Wood was written by this Japanese author of The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle and Kafka on the Shore.

In Kafka on the Shore, Nakata’s search for one of these animals leads him on an adventure with the truck driver Hoshino. The grinning “Cheshire” one of these animals appears in Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland.

answers: Louis IX of France [accept Saint Louis; prompt on Louis]
Vichy France <European History, AK and JP><ed. AH>
parts: This man was mistakenly imprisoned on Devil’s Island for nearly five years in place of the actual perpetrator, Ferdinand Esterhazy. Émile Zola wrote J’accuse against the unlawful jailing of this man.

At the urging of pope Gregory IX, this French king had around 12,000 Talmuds and other Jewish books burned in Paris. This King halted Henry III’s continental expansion at the Battle of Taillebourg [[“tie-boor”]].
Jews were persecuted by this Nazi puppet government in France during World War II. It was led by Philippe Pétain.

answers: Resurrection Symphony [accept but DO NOT REVEAL Mahler Symphony No. 2, prompt on Symphony No. 2]
The Song of the Earth [accept Das Lied von der Erde] <Auditory Art, OC><ed. OC>
parts: Name this work in C minor that sets to music Friedrich Klopstock’s hymn “Die Auferstehung,” which includes the line “rise again, yes, you shall rise again.”
The Resurrection Symphony is by this composer of many massive symphonies including the “Titan” and Symphony of a Thousand.
Mahler based this composition, scored for two voices and orchestra, on several Chinese poems. He named this symphony without a number in an attempt to avoid the “curse of the ninth.”

answers: Pierre Bezukhov [accept either underlined portion] <Long Fiction, AH><ed. OC>
parts: Name this long Tolstoy work, which is set during Napoleon's invasion of Russia and features the convoluted love life of Natasha Rostova.
Natasha's engagement to Prince Andrey is broken after an attempted elopement with this man, who is rumored to have had an affair with his sister Hélène.
Hélène is the first wife of this other War and Peace character, who ends up marrying Natasha after failing to kill Napoleon.
Name this American city built on the shores of the Schuylkill River, where Max Schmitt and Dr. Samuel Gross were immortalized through Eakins’ work.

Eakins is largely responsible for introducing this visual medium to the American artist’s studio. Eadweard Muybridge used it to study the motion of horses, while Eakins used it to study the motion of humans.
Another little-known contribution of Eakins was his instrumental role in the education of this first internationally-acclaimed African-American artist who painted The Banjo Lesson.

answers: The Clash of Civilizations <Social Science, AH><ed. JB>
parts: Name this discipline that investigates systems of governance and political behavior.

By analyzing regime changes throughout the 20th century, Fukuyama concluded that the “liberal” form of this kind of representational government developed in ancient Athens will become internationally dominant.

American political scientist Samuel P. Huntington directly responded to Fukuyama’s claims of international peace with a work of this title, which holds that conflict will arise from cultural differences.
Name this body system whose function is to break down food and transfer nutrients into the body’s internal environment. The GI tract is made up of organs that participate in this system.

Interstitial cells of Cajal in the GI tract act as these cells, creating slow wave potentials to cause rhythmic contraction of smooth muscle. These cells continuously undergo action potentials and allow the SA node to function.
This term refers to the radial contractions and relaxations of the circular smooth muscle in the digestive tract that carry a bolus of food down the tract.
The protagonist of this work poisons all the nuns in a convent, including his daughter Abigail. He later dies by falling into a boiling cauldron.

The cauldron was actually set up as a trap for this character. The governor of Malta, Ferneze, confiscates all of Barrabas’ wealth to pay off this Turkish prince after Barrabas refuses to convert to Christianity.
The Jew of Malta is by this English author. He also wrote about the title character selling his soul to Mephistopheles in Doctor Faustus.

answers: Challenger disaster [accept equivalents mentioning Space Shuttle Challenger]
parts: Name this January 28, 1986 event caused by the failure of O-ring seals. It killed seven crew members, including one who would have been the first teacher in space.
The disaster prompted President Ronald Reagan to postpone this annual address given by the president. He gave the famous “Touched the face of God” speech instead.
Reagan formed this presidential commission to investigate the disaster. This body found that the Morton- Thiokol Chemical Corporation was at fault for the event.

answers: battery [prompt on but do not reveal voltaic cells]
galvanic cell [accept voltaic cell, prompt on electrochemical cell, do not accept or prompt on “electrolytic cell”]
standard hydrogen electrode [accept SHE, prompt on hydrogen electrode] <Chemistry, CT><ed. KLei>
parts: Name these things, which are often sold in sizes like double A and triple A.
Batteries are made up of these things connected in series. These things generate electrical energy through the transfer of electrons in a spontaneous reaction.
To assign absolute cell potentials to galvanic cells, the cell potential is compared to the standard reduction potential of this electrode, which contains a platinum electrode.

answers: New England Patriots [accept either underlined portion]
Michael Strahan <Pop Culture/Mixed Academic, AK><ed. KLu and AK>
parts: The heavy favorites were this team. This team was led by quarterback Tom Brady and had just become the second team to complete an undefeated regular season.
This noted hoodie-wearer coached the Patriots to the undefeated season, but failed to defeat the New York Giants in the game. He is regarded as one of the foremost defensive minds in NFL history.
In his final season, this Giants defensive end helped defeat the Patriots. This man set the record for most sacks in a season with 22.5 in 2001.

answers: Mark Sanford <Current Events, AC><ed. KLu and AK>
parts: Joe Crowley lost re-nomination in New York’s 14th Congressional District to this woman, a self-described “democratic socialist” who became the youngest woman elected to Congress.

In this state’s 7th district, longtime representative Michael Capuano lost to progressive upstart Ayanna Pressley. Pressley later won the general election in this state, along with this state’s junior senator, Elizabeth Warren.
In South Carolina’s 1st District, this congressman was defeated by Trump-endorsed Katie Arrington. This congressman resigned as South Carolina governor following a 2009 extramarital affair.

answers: Peasants’ Revolt [accept Wat Tyler Revolt or Great Rising]
Black Death [accept Black Plague or Great Plague or The Plague; prompt on Bubonic Plague]
John of Gaunt [prompt on John or Duke of Lancaster] <European History, AK><ed. AH>
parts: Name this revolt, a 1381 popular uprising against Richard II commonly known by its leader’s name.
One of the Peasants’ Revolt causes was this 14th century pandemic which claimed the lives of over 75 million people across Europe.
Another of the Revolt’s causes was this man’s imposition of a poll tax. His marriage to the Infanta Constance led to an unsuccessful bid for the Castilian throne.
Sound from wind instruments consists of waves of this type, in which particles of the medium oscillate parallel to the direction of the wave. These waves are contrasted with transverse waves.

Clarinets and other reed instruments can be modeled as pipes with one open end. Such instruments have one of these points at the closed end, which undergo no displacement during oscillations of the standing wave.

Since pipes with one open end only have odd harmonic numbers, their resonant frequencies are given by the product of the harmonic number and wave speed divided by this multiple of the length of the pipe.

answers: Harlem Renaissance [do not accept or prompt on “Renaissance”] <Non-epic Poetry, JB><ed. OC and AB>
parts: One of the founders of the movement was this Martinician poet and essayist who wrote a postcolonial interpretation of The Tempest in which Caliban is the hero.
This writer analyzed the Négritude movement in his essay “Orphée Noir.” This French existentialist philosopher also wrote Nausea and No Exit.
Négritude was strongly influenced by this American artistic and literary movement. Prominent Négritude poet Leopold Senghor praised Claude McKay as the founder of this movement.

answers: Seagram building <Other Fine Arts, AH><ed. OC>
parts: The first director of the Bauhaus was this prolific international-style architect whose works panned from the Fagus Factory in the early 1910s to the Pan Am building in the 1960s.
This last director of the Bauhaus designed the Farnsworth House, Lake Shore Drive apartments, and Tugendhat villa. He coined the maxim “less is more.”

Mies’ best known work is this Manhattan skyscraper that contains the Four Seasons Restaurant. It was the most expensive skyscraper of its time and was lavishly decorated with bronze, travertine, and marble.

answers: Korea [do not accept or prompt on North or South Korea]
Hachiman [accept Hachiman-sin or Yawata no Kami] <Mythology, DY><ed. AH>
parts: Name this Asian peninsula that neighbors Japan. It was prophesied that Emperor Chuai would conquer it, but his disbelief enraged the kami and he died, leaving his wife Jingu to conquer it.
Jingu was prophesied to invade Korea by three children of this deity. This creator god made the islands of Japan with his spouse, Izanami.
Name this Japanese kami of war, often identified with Ojin, the son of Empress Jingu. His name translates to “God of Eight Banners.”
